pros: great place to work for
cons: limited pay at times due to budget

pros: - It's a good student job with consistent hours.
cons: - It's a federal work-study job. It's not their fault, just a reality of the situation. With this comes limited pay, hours, and a touch of micro-managing for a job that really doesn't require that. Overall, I'm content with the job.

pros: Great colleagues, location is good
cons: State bureaucracy is the worst...

pros: Great work environment and connection to your professors.
cons: Parking in Baltimore city and walking the area late a night.

pros: benefits were good all around
cons: no room for growth and no raises

pros: Great benefits with plenty of opportunity for advancement
cons: No option to work remotely

pros: Working with the Career Center at University of Baltimore was really fast-paced really positive. My Director of Career Services was very well-studied and always trained her staff and I in advising / student coaching best practices with workshops every other month (or more). This is definitely the job to be in if you love working with students, pulling off career & experiential workshops and meeting with employers.
cons: I tend to work at my own pace, which wasn't suitable for needs of the position I held. University of Baltimore's Career Center has to work quickly due to its small staff. After a month-long onboarding session, the rubber hits the road and you need to take care of your responsibilities as assigned. DO NOT TAKE this job if you're not well-organized or haven't mastered your time management/productivity skills.

job_title: Associate Professor of Finance in Baltimore, MD
pros: Interacting with students is fun and rewarding. Doing research is even more interesting.
cons: The administrative team, in particular the president seems not functioning well. The culture seems to be that "talking more and doing less".

pros: Faculty, students and some staff are highly engaged and supportive. Benefits such as vacation time are great, when you're allowed to use them.
cons: My division suffered a revolving door of poor leadership over a period of years. Reckless spending of limited funds, zero transparency around promotion and raises, and pathetically few opportunities for professional development. A finger pointing surveillance culture that holds the rank and file workers responsible for low enrollments, but never the leadership.

pros: It is a great place to work!
cons: I have no complaints about UB.

job_title: Digital Forensics Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: gets you experience in the field
cons: bad pay and a lot of work

pros: Excellent team dynamic, wonderful professionals, and a student population committed to their career development. Truly puts a focus on good customer service and excellent performance.
cons: No major cons, although cross-departmental communication can be inconsistent, particularly staff to faculty and vice-versa.

pros: Opportunity to assist students in learning
cons: Low compensation paid to adjunct professors

job_title: Clinical Teaching Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: This is the most supportive environment I have ever worked in. Highly recommend!
cons: Teaching evening classes can be demanding on your schedule, but it's rewarding teaching students who bring so much work experience into the classroom learning environment.

pros: Good place and people to work
cons: Always in a fiscal crisis

pros: Overall I felt like the work/life balance was pretty healthy.
cons: There weren’t many opportunities for advancement.

pros: Holidays,Healthcare,Retirement ,Tuition remission, technology, community
cons: Slow process Advancement Salary adjustment

pros: They give you the freedom to discover who you are as a professional.
cons: It may not be the best financially for an adult with lots of bills.

pros: The health benefits and vacation time are incredible. Exempt employees get 20 days of annual leave at the start of employment along with 3 personal days and holidays.
cons:
The morale at the university is horrible right now. There have been multiple lay offs without notice and without explanation. Most people walked around pretty worried their job would be gone tomorrow. They got rid of the Registrar for no reason and passed the duties onto other people. Instead of investing in their employees with pay increases all of the raises go to senior level administrators. The new Provost has staffed her office with more $100k salaried administrators at this very small school, than that of universities twice the size. It was so disappointing to watch highly intelligent, creative, and engaged employees get knocked down because of dirty administrative politics. 

For example a national search was held for the position of Provost. The entire university became excited over the candidates and the chance for needed growth and change. We put in our votes, but the President selected a candidate without taking into consideration the votes of faculty and staff. He selected someone that wasn't even put forward by the search committee. Very dirty politics that continued to damper morale.

pros: Great benefits and faculty are poised to keep the vessel sea worthy.
cons: Little or no opportunity for advancement and professional development is null.  Financial resources for the most basic things are difficult to come by, (e.g. Once had to ask colleagues for paper clips).  Third-tier institution selling a top-tier offer.

pros: You are paid very well, for not very hard work.
cons: no benefits, contract for two years and after two years if the don't become a state employee then you are let go. it is very student flexible. the structure is poorly organized and they expect you to work hard but don't pay benefits or give healthcare if you are not a state employee. However, if you are looking for a better job it's fine to work at for six or so months. You can work the entire two years and the only good thing other than your coworkers is the decent pay for not to hard work.

pros: Benefits are the main pros
cons: Culture can be toxic. Definitely a sense of job insecurity and leadership does nothing to ease this. Also, leadership across multiple departments do a poor job of helping employees grow. Annual performance and goal reviews can be arbitrary and best, if not retreated as just general paperwork to turn into HR. The culture doesn't take kindly to using sick and vacation. Many employees have large amounts of this time saved up but can be written up for using it. Using sick leave for 2 occurrences in a given period will lead to being written up. This is the reason many employees have large amounts of time saved up.

job_title: Student A/V Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Regular payments and structured systems for doing everything help to take the guesswork out of what you're doing. The fact that you're free to surf the web when you're done with your tasks is a plus as well, though that carries its own hazards.
cons: Because of the structure, doing anything outside of the ordinary usually goes through several departments and can take some time to get done. Some employees also have a chip on their shoulder, but have been in their positions for too long to be objectively reviewed by management. Many of the student assistants have poor work ethics.

pros: The shining light of the school is Kurt Schmoke. The events planned by the Student Events Boards are very well done, as well as the keynote speakers UB is able to attain.
cons: The downside is ALL parts of administration. The bursars department probably has the best service and maybe that's because they are happy to take students money, but all other departments there seems to be low morale, especially with the recent budget cuts and a few longtime staff members being laid off.

review_title: The reason why lower-tier is lower-tier
pros: A truly low-stress environment; there tends to be very little performance pressure on employees. This environment is also at least tacitly encouraging for intrapeneurs, since few people will try to stop you. The school generally has a good idea of its role in the state system, which is fairly unusual, and doesn't spend a lot of time trying to become something it isn't--a major pitfall for universities everywhere.
cons: Staff is small and either very inexperienced or legacy employees who should have been let go twenty years ago. Despite this mix, culture is still very heavily siloed, with larger units such as the Law School often operating at odds with, and even in open contempt of, the larger institutional picture. Many employees in key positions are drastically underqualified. There seems to be little political will to change this, or to encourage smart people to work for the University.

review_title: It was the best of time, it was the worst of times
pros: The students are serious about advancing their education.  Many of the faculty and staff are dedicated to making the educational experience one that is truly beneficial.  Courses are offered at times when full-time workers can attend.
cons: Leadership is inconsistent and often out of touch with current educational and work climate.  Location is in a less than desirable area of city.

review_title: Frustrating, all lower employees know what needs to be done to make the university great, but upper managermen
pros:
-People are Genuine
-Flexible work environment
cons: -Upper Management doesn't listen or care what students and lower empoyees have to say regarding improving the university. Instead they waste time and money creating things which aren't thought out and make no sense ex. Varsity, MICA and UB meal plan etc.

pros: Students,staff and  meeting people from different parts of the word that attends the university
cons: some of the people in my line of work have some ways about  working as a team.  I feel sometimes ipersonally go beyound and above some duties i have to satisifiethe university of baltimore. i do feel appreciated, but some days i feel need more of a challenging positon.

review_title: Good experience but a lack of responsibility on keeping work area discrimination free.
pros: Liked working in an student based employer.  The main goal is to provided students with education.
cons: Area is controlled by a small group of people and if you dont fit in their criteria, will make your life imposible.  Made frew great people move on to other jobs by preasure.

pros: Flexibility is a major Pro as well as the pay compared to all of the other campus jobs available
cons: While the horly rate is high, the amount of time you work is limited to your financial aid reward. the work environment is stressful and there are a lot of personalities to navigate around, including the students and faculty.

pros: The people that I worked with were really caring and professional. As an peer educator, we had flexible work time and we had easy access to the resources.
cons: There're not any cons in my mind for this position. I wish they could divided work between us, instead of giving us a task and leaving it to us.

pros: Amazing people, relaxed but professional workplace environment.
cons: Time sheets are a pain if you forget to fill one out. Out accounting process seems to have hiccups but its not a big deal.

review_title: Awesome climate and enviornment to learn and grow.
job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Work-Life Balance and MSB is AWESOME!!! Many of the offices are so willing to help the students. We got things done!
cons: Salary, pay was not enough to destroy your car driving.

pros: Gained a lot of experience in my student assistant position. The hours are very flexible because they understand you're a student.
cons: Most positions hire with your financial aid. So once your work study is depleted, they will most likely ask you to stop working or work less.

job_title: Research and Lab Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Flexibility of schedule, learning more about software and hardware and ability to do homework
cons: I do not have many cons from this position, but one thing to note was the lack of structure in this position.

pros: Excellent environment, positive faculty attitudes
cons: As in many univerities, a few people have either exceeded their experation date or have been promoted beyoond their level of competency.  Few means <= 3.

job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Baltimore, MD
pros:
My employer was aware of my duties as a student and was very flexible.
Friendly office environment.
cons: The higher ups above my boss made it hard at times to push good ideas through.

no specified niche area, except their law school, they still struggle how to market themselves
students lack quant skills due to admit all policy in most grad programs

pros: Admin was very encouraging of a healthy work-life balance. Relaxed and supportive working environment.
cons: Pay could be abysmal, and raises were largely insignificant (pennies on the dollar).

review_title: If you have all the pretty buildings but there's no faculty will the students still come?
pros: The students are still great.
cons: The administration is completely out of control. Faculty considerations are an afterthought.
